description: All foreign citizens, including U.S. citizens, who are residents of Uruguay are prohibited from exiting Uruguay for tourism purposes. The prohibition on the departure of Uruguayan residents also applies to those who have Uruguayan residency applications in progress, and applies whether you are flying on commercial or charter service.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description:
On 2 June, the Uruguayan government issued a decree modifying the conditions to enter and leave the country under the national emergency declared as a consequence of COVID-19.1 Beyond Uruguayan citizens and permanent residents, the new decree authorizes foreign nationals to enter the country in these situations:

Family reunification cases involving parents, spouses, concubines or single children with incapacities; and
Duly and previously authorized transitory entrances regarding labor, economic, business or judicial related affairs.
Currently, other foreign nationals are still forbidden to enter Uruguay.
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: On July 6, 2020, Uruguay’s Ministry of Public Health (MPH) issued Ordinance 649/2020, requiring Uruguayan nationals and foreigners entering the country—whether by air, land, or sea—to prove they have tested negative for COVID-19 within the previous 72 hours.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Uruguay takes actions to ensure the population the availability of gel alcohol necessary for all the demand, for which the Ancap production plant in Paysandú was reactivated. (03/15/2020)
Uruguay ordered 200.000 additional vaccines against influenza, and confirmed the arrival of 600.000 for 30th of March. This was announced on March 13.

description: The Government of Uruguay announced that from April 13, 150-200,000 facemasks would be distributed on buses free of charge.

description: Uruguay carries out about 1,100 random tests in Rivera, starting on Monday 25, to detect possible cases of coronavirus, and expanding the number of intensive care beds in the capital city. Health services will also be increased, with the addition of two ambulances, one of which will exclusively transport COVID-19 patients.

Uruguay carries out about 1,100 random tests in Rivera, starting on Monday 25, to detect possible cases of coronavirus, and expanding the number of intensive care beds in the capital city. Health services will also be increased, with the addition of two ambulances, one of which will exclusively transport COVID-19 patients.

Uruguay carries out about 1,100 random tests in Rivera, starting on Monday 25, to detect possible cases of coronavirus, and expanding the number of intensive care beds in the capital city. Health services will also be increased, with the addition of two ambulances, one of which will exclusively transport COVID-19 patients.

A meeting of the various health institutions and the government took place on April 7, and the agreement of a common testing protocol, led to an immediate and significant jump in the number of tests carried out. By July testing was regularly over 2000 cases per day
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: "Local law enforcement officials will be establishing checkpoints to diminish movement in Uruguay ahead of the holiday week which begins on April 6."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From April 1 to April 12, the Ministry of Interior has stated that local law enforcement officials will be establishing checkpoints to diminish movement in Uruguay ahead of the holiday week which begins on April 6.  Local law enforcement will be present at department borders and on major roads. Uruguay is encouraging diminished movement during this popular tourism week in light of ongoing COVID-19 concerns.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Uruguay is enforcing a 50% reduction in the number of public transport units that circulate on weekends and disinfection of vehicles once each trip is finished. The measure is mandatory and was ordered by the Ministry of Transportation and Public Works. (01/04/2020)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Uruguay announces new checkpoints on the Rivera border, to reduce the movement of people and vehicles

Uruguay establishes working subgroups within various institutions, including e.g.: National Defense, WHO, Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo (Interamerican development bank), Facultad de Ciencias Instituto Pasteur (Science Faculty of Pasteur Institute), National Emergency Board, directors of the Health ministry on March 3rd.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Uruguay puts together and commissions an Expert Commision on March 15.

description: Uruguay has assembled a scientific advisory group to the President to advise on reopening the country.

description: Uruguay creates a high-level group to evaluate the different measures applied so far by the Government, made up of the director of the Office of Planning and Budget (OPP), Isaac Alfie, the mathematician Fernando Paganini, the biochemist Rafael Radi and the gastroenterologist Henry Cohen. (04/17/2020)
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On August 3 museums and theaters reopened, after four months of suspended activities. Above all, social distancing measures are in place. Anxiously awaited, football matches returned (without spectators) on August 8.
type_text: allowing certain types of mass gatherings such as reopening museums, theatres and football matches

description:
Uruguay orders quarantine for people with COVID-19, their direct contact persons and anyone with fever and respiratory symptoms who stayed in high risk areas. As well as anyone who enters Uruguay coming from 
Spain, Italy, France, Germany, China, South Korea, Japan, Singapore or Iran.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2020, Uruguay orders quarantine for people with COVID-19, their direct contact persons and anyone with fever and respiratory symptoms who stayed in high risk areas. As well as anyone who enters Uruguay coming from Spain, Italy, France, Germany, China, South Korea, Japan, Singapore or Iran.

description: Uruguay implements home quarantine for certified medical and non-medical workers with health insurance for the first three days of inactivity.

Uruguay implemented a 7- day mandatory quarantine for all foreigners and non-foreigners entering the country. On day 7 of quarantine it will be required to have a second swab taken and wait for a negative result before being allowed to finish your quarantine period. Alternatively, it is possible to quarantine for 14 days without having to take the second test
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Uruguay promotes smart working whenever possible, both at public and private level, in order to respect social distancing
On April 10, the government of Uruguay announced that from April 13 anyone using or working on public transport should wear a facemask.
Uruguay announced that as of Monday, April 13, the frequencies of collective transport will be doubled in peak hours, to avoid crowds within the units
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: Uruguay announced that as of Monday, April 13, the frequencies of collective transport will be doubled in peak hours, to avoid crowds within the units
